page.title: List of fatal, unprovoked shark attacks in the United States

revision.text: This is a '''list of fatal, unprovoked [[shark attack]]s that occurred in United States''' territorial waters by decade in reverse chronological order. A pink background indicates that the greater weight of the evidence suggests that this victim died from a cause of death other than a shark attack; however, at least one source at some point in time has identified shark attack as the cause of death. == 2010s == {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="100"|Location!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Comments |- | Arthur Medici, 26 || September 15, 2018 || [[Wellfleet, Massachusetts]] || Unconfirmed, presumed to be a [[great white shark]] ||At around noon on Saturday September 15, Medici was attacked near Newcomb Hollow Beach on Cape Cod, and was transferred to Cape Cod Hospital. He died in the hospital a few hours later, in the first fatal shark attack in Massachusetts since 1936.{{cite web| author=Sullivan, Emily |title=Swimmer Dead After Shark Attack On Cape Cod |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/09/15/648295206/swimmer-dead-after-shark-attack-on-cape-cod |publisher=NPR |date= September 15, 2018 |accessdate = September 15, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/newcomb-hollow-beach-wellfeet-massachusetts-deadly-shark-attack-today-2018-09-15/ |title="It was like right out of that movie 'Jaws'": Man dies after shark attack on Cape Cod |publisher=CBS News |date=September 15, 2018 |accessdate = September 15, 2018}} This attack occurred only a few weeks after another man was non-fatally injured by what was determined to be a great white shark in the nearby town of [[Truro, Massachusetts|Truro]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/08/31/state-biologist-greg-skomal-confident-great-white-shark-was-responsible-for-truro-attack/WDLz8Jspuaot4zTZ77JhDI/story.html |title=State biologist ‘confident’ great white shark was responsible for Truro attack |author=Annear, Stene |date=August 31, 2018 |accessdate=September 15, 2018}} |- | Margaret C. Cruse, 65 || April 29, 2015 || [[Maui]], [[Hawaii]] || unconfirmed, presumed to be a [[Tiger shark]]{{cite web |title=Woman killed by shark in Hawaii |publisher=trackingsharks.com|date=April 30, 2015 |url = http://www.trackingsharks.com/woman-killed-by-shark-in-hawaii |accessdate= May 2, 2015 }} || Cruse, a resident of [[Kihei, Hawaii]], was bitten in the upper torso while snorkeling by an unknown species of shark at a popular surfing spot known as "The Dumps" near [[Makena, Hawaii|Makena]], [[Maui]]. Her lifeless body was found floating face-down by other snorkelers. She also lost an arm in the attack.{{cite web|title=Shark kills woman in Hawaii; sightings prompt warnings in SoCal|publisher=Fox News|date=April 30, 2015|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/04/30/shark-kills-woman-in-hawaii-prompts-beach-closures/?intcmp=latestnews&intcamp=latestnews|accessdate= April 30, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Authorities identify woman who died in shark attack off Maui|date=April 30, 2015|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/28934069/deadly-attack-in-waters-near-maui-prompts-beach-closures|accessdate=April 30, 2015}} |- | Patrick A. Briney, 57 || December 2, 2013 || [[Maui]], [[Hawaii]] || unconfirmed, presumed to be a [[Tiger shark]] || Briney, a resident of [[Washington (state)|Washington State]], was fishing from a [[kayak]] with his right foot dangling over the side, which was bitten by a shark. He died while being transported to shore. The attack occurred about 500 yards off Keawakapu Beach in the [[Makena State Park|Makena State Recreation Area]] on [[Maui]], [[Hawaii]].{{cite news|title=Victim of Maui shark attack identified as Washington man|author=Kakesako, Gregg| date=December 2, 2013|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/breaking/234128381.html}} |- | Jana Lutteropp, 20 || August 14, 2013 || [[Maui]], [[Hawaii]] || unconfirmed, presumed to be a [[Tiger shark]]{{cite news|title=Jana Lutteropp: Shark Attack Victim Told Rescuer 'I'm Going To Die|publisher=The Inquisitr|date=August 22, 2013|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/916413/jana-lutteropp-shark-attack-victim-told-rescuer-im-going-to-die/}} || Lutteropp, a German tourist, died on August 21, 2013 one week after her right arm was bitten off by a shark while snorkeling 50 to 100 yards off Palauea beach in [[Makena, Hawaii|Makena, Maui]].{{cite news|title=German tourist dies days after losing arm in Hawaii shark attack|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57599624/german-tourist-dies-after-losing-arm-in-hawaii-shark-attack/|publisher=CBS News.com|date=August 21, 2012}}{{cite news|title=German tourist Jana Lutteropp dies a week after losing arm in Maui shark attack|date=August 22, 2013|author=Williams, Rob|publisher=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/german-tourist-jana-lutteropp-dies-a-week-after-losing-arm-in-maui-shark-attack-8779343.html}} |- | Francisco Javier Solorio Jr., 39 || October 23, 2012 ||[[Surf Beach, California|Surf Beach]], [[California]] || [[Great white shark]] || Solorio died after he was bitten on the left side of his upper torso by a great white shark while surfing. The attack occurred at [[Surf Beach, California|Surf Beach]] near [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] in [[Santa Barbara County, California]], just two years after a fatal attack in the same location. Authorities from the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Office positively identified the species involved in the attack as a {{convert|15|-|16|ft}} great white shark.{{cite news|title=California surfer killed in shark attack|url=http://www.centurylink.net/news/read.php?rip_id=%3CDA23GJGG1%40news.ap.org%3E&ps=1018|publisher=CenturyLink|date=October 23, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Great white shark killed California surfer, officials say|date=October 25, 2012|publisher=CNN|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/24/us/california-shark-attack-death/index.html?hpt=hp_t3}} |- | Lucas McKaine Ransom, 19 || October 22, 2010 ||[[Surf Beach, California|Surf Beach]], [[California]] || [[Great white shark]] || Ransom died after a great white shark pulled him off his [[bodyboard]] just before 9 a.m. about {{convert|100|yd}} off Surf Beach near [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] in [[Santa Barbara County, California]]. He suffered the loss of his left leg, resulting in [[hypovolemia|massive blood loss]].{{cite web|title=Expert: Great White Shark Likely Killed Calif. Surfer|publisher=AOL News|url=http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/calif-surfer-bleeds-to-death-after-shark-attack/19685959|accessdate=2010-10-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025084308/http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/calif-surfer-bleeds-to-death-after-shark-attack/19685959|archivedate=2010-10-25|df=}}{{cite news|title=Update: Experts Say Great White Killed Student|url=http://www.keyt.com/news/local/Deadly-Shark-Attack-105537773.html|date=October 22, 2010|publisher=KEY News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023182610/http://www.keyt.com/news/local/Deadly-Shark-Attack-105537773.html|archivedate=October 23, 2010|df=}} On October 25, 2010, the Santa Barbara County coroner confirmed the species as great white after conferring with shark experts from the Los Angeles-based Shark Research Committee. The shark that attacked Ransom is believed to have been {{convert|17|-|18|ft}} long, weighing approximately {{convert|4000|lb|kg|0}}.{{cite news|title=Coroner: Great white shark likely killed Calif man|date=October 25, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=AOL News|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2010/10/25/general-us-shark-attack_8043572.html |accessdate=2010-10-26}} |- | Stephen Howard Schafer, 38|| February 3, 2010 || [[Stuart, Florida|Stuart Beach]], [[Florida]] ||[[Bull shark]]{{cite news|title=Expert: Great white shark killed Martin surfer |publisher=wptv.com|date=February 9, 2010|url=http://www.wptv.com/content/news/martin/stuart/story/Expert-Bull-shark-killed-Martin-surfer/YEk9yr8W2E2r02XFf_FmdQ.cspx|accessdate=2010-02-11}} || Schafer was attacked while [[kitesurfing]] around 4:15 p.m. about {{convert|500|yd}} off an unguarded section of a beach south of [[Stuart, Florida|Stuart Beach]] in [[Martin County, Florida]]. Authorities initially thought multiple sharks may have been involved in the incident due to reports by rescuers that he was surrounded by sharks. The Martin County medical examiner's office concluded he died from massive blood loss from a leg wound.{{cite news |title=Kiteboard surfer attacked by sharks dies form injuries, authorities report| url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2010/feb/03/florida-kiteboard-surfer-attacked-by-sharks-dies/|accessdate=2010-02-03 | publisher= TCPalm.com}}{{cite news|title=Expert: Don't rush to blame great white sharks for Stuart kiteboarder's death |url=http://www.latimes.com/fl-shark-attack-stuart-20100204,0,6140639.story?track=rss |publisher=LA Times |date=February 4, 2010 |accessdate=2010-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208190627/http://www.latimes.com/fl-shark-attack-stuart-20100204%2C0%2C6140639.story?track=rss |archivedate=February 8, 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Massive blood loss killed shark attack victim|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/35257862/ns/us_news-life/|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=2010-02-05}}{{cite news|title=Scientist says knowing what shark attacked and why can prevent fear, future trajedy|url=https://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/scientist-says-knowing-what-shark-attacked-and-why-can-prevent-fear-future-tragedy/WXCNTLx0MbFMPNRkRAmFkN/|author=Kirley, James|publisher=Palm Beach Post|date=February 4, 2010|accessdate=2010-02-08}} |- |} ==2000s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#0099CC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- |Richard A. Snead, 60 || September 12, 2009|| Unconfirmed || Snead died while swimming in the Atlantic Ocean at twilight off the beach in the Whale Head Bay area of [[Corolla, North Carolina]], near mile post 4½. His body was found washed up on the beach in [[Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina]].{{cite web|title=Fatal Shark Attack in Corolla, NC|url=http://www.carolinabeachtoday.com/2009/09/fatal-shark-attack-in-corolla-nc.html|date=September 19, 2009|accessdate=2010-02-03}} Final autopsy results, released on January 5, 2010, concluded Snead's death appeared to be from drowning. This conclusion conflicted, however, with an initial autopsy conducted at [[East Carolina University]] which said he died of shark bites.{{cite news|title=ME: Shark Bite Not Responsible for Ross Township Man's Death|url=http://www.wpxi.com/news/20989479/detail.html|accessdate=2010-02-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130054857/http://www.wpxi.com/news/20989479/detail.html|archivedate=2010-01-30|df=}}{{cite news|title=Swim was regular outing for shark bite victim |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/24313314?GT1=43001#.UeVu4421F8G |date=April 25, 2008 |accessdate=2013-07-16 |publisher=NBC News}} |- |David Roger Martin, 66|| April 25, 2008 || [[Great white shark]] || Martin was killed at approximately 7:20 a.m. while swimming with a group of eight other triathletes off a beach in [[Solana Beach, California]]. The victim was bitten across both thighs.{{cite news|title=Beach warnings in effect after shark kills triathlete|newspaper=San Diego Union-Tribune|author=Rodgers, Terry|date=April 26, 2008|url=http://legacy.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20080426-9999-1n26shark.html}} |- |-Jacob Paul Calle, 27 || May 4, 2007 || [[Bull shark]] || Calle was killed while searching for hermit crabs with his toes off of Stewart Beach in Galveston, TX. Jacob's body was lacerated, with major external bleeding from his chest and abdomen. |- | Jamie Marie Daigle, 14 || June 25, 2005 || [[Bull shark]] || Daigle was killed while swimming with a friend on boogie boards about {{convert|200|yd}} off a beach in [[Walton County, Florida]], {{convert|8|mi}} east of [[Destin, Florida]]. Witnesses estimated the shark was {{convert|6|-|8|ft}} long. Her left leg was severed and she died of massive blood loss.{{cite news | title=Florida beaches open after shark attack | date=June 26, 2005 | publisher=CNN.com | url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/US/06/26/shark.attack/ | accessdate=2006-04-18}} |- | Randy Fry, 50 || August 15, 2004 || Great white shark || Fry was killed while diving for abalone with a friend in {{convert|15|-|20|ft}} of water {{convert|150|ft|m}} from shore off [[Mendocino, California]], near Kibesillah Rock. His headless body was recovered the next day. His head washed ashore {{convert|2|mi|km}} north on September 3. The bite radius was {{convert|18|in|cm}}, allowing experts to extrapolate the shark was {{convert|16|-|18|ft}} long.{{cite web | title=Randy Fry Memorial Page | publisher=NorCal Skin Divers Club | url=http://www.norcalskindivers.com/randy.htm | accessdate=2006-04-18 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061127014617/http://www.norcalskindivers.com/randy.htm | archivedate=2006-11-27 | df= }}{{cite web|publisher=Outside.online|title=Killer Abs|url=http://outside.away.com/outside/features/200604/northern-california-great-white-sharks-1.html|date=April 2006}} |- | Willis R. McInnis, 57 || April 7, 2004 || [[Tiger shark]] || Attacked while surfing off Pohaku Park, [[Maui, Hawaii]], McInnis died a short time after the attack as a result of blood loss from severe wounds to his right thigh and calf.{{cite news | title=Shark kills Maui surfer | publisher=The Honolulu Advertiser | date= April 8, 2004 | author=Wilson Christie | url=http://www.moolelo.com/shark-kills-surfer.html | accessdate=2006-04-18}} |- | Courtney Marcher, 22 || April 4, 2004 || Unconfirmed, possibly a tiger shark || Marcher disappeared while surfing at Velzyland, the [[North Shore (Oahu)|North Shore]] of [[Oahu, Hawaii]], around 8:45 a.m. Her undamaged surfboard was found {{convert|3|mi}} off [[Kaena Point]] by a fisherman three days later, {{convert|18|mi|km}} north of her last known location and consistent with currents.{{cite news |title=Woman's surfboard found |author1=Lum, Curtis |author2=Eloise Aguiar |lastauthoramp=yes|publisher=The Honolulu Advertiser | date=April 9, 2004 |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Apr/09/ln/ln20a.html | accessdate=2010-10-26}} Unusual serrated markings on the board's ankle leash were suggestive of shark involvement,{{cite news |title=Shark expert looks at surfer's leash |publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date=April 9, 2004 |author=Antone, Rod |url=http://www.starbulletin.com/2004/04/09/news/story6.html |accessdate=2006-04-18}} but analysis by the state Shark Task Force proved inconclusive, with experts divided as to what the marks represented.{{cite news | title=Town to honor missing surfer |author=Toth, Catherine E. |publisher=The Honolulu Advertiser | date=June 28, 2004 |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Jun/28/ln/ln05a.html | accessdate=2010-10-26}} Police reported Marcher had a history of seizures and may have run into trouble in the water, although she had been taking medication to control epilepsy and had no recent history of illness. On the day she vanished, wave faces averaged {{convert|6|ft}}, but she was described as healthy and a strong swimmer. |- | Deborah Blanche Franzman, 50 || August 19, 2003 || [[Great white shark]] || Franzman was attacked at approximately 8:15 a.m. while swimming in {{convert|15|-|20|ft|m}} of water {{convert|75|yd|m|0}} off Avila Pier, [[Avila Beach, California]].{{cite news|title=Swimmer Dies After Apparent Shark Attack |publisher=NBCSandiego.com |date=August 19, 2003 |url=http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/2415997/detail.html |accessdate=2006-04-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060112000713/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/2415997/detail.html |archivedate=January 12, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news |title=Woman Killed in Shark Attack |author=Connell, Sally Ann |author2=Kenneth R. Weiss |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/aug/20/local/me-shark20 |newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=August 20, 2003 |accessdate=27 January 2011}} She was bitten on the left hip and lower right leg by a shark estimated to be {{convert|15|-|18|ft}} long.{{cite news |title=Woman Killed in Shark Attack Died Quickly |author=Connell, Sally Ann |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/aug/21/local/me-shark21 |newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=August 21, 2003 |accessdate=27 January 2011}} According to witnesses, Franzman was swimming with seals alongside a line of buoys in a full wetsuit before the animals "suddenly scattered". Franzman screamed for help after the shark struck twice and swam off, but apparently lost consciousness and drifted face-down in the water before lifeguards pulled her to shore, by which time she had died of blood loss.{{cite news |title=Swimmer killed in likely shark attack, County's first such fatality in 46 years |author=Sneed, David |author2=Ryan Huff |page=A1 |newspaper=The Tribune |location=San Luis Obispo, CA |date=August 20, 2003 }} Her wounds included a severed femoral artery. Franzman was only the second shark-related fatality in [[San Luis Obispo County]] history since the April 1957 death of Peter Savino. |-Bethany Hamilton, 13: Tiger Shark, Bethany was attacked while surfing with friend Alana Blanchard. While her left arm dangling in the water, a tiger shark jumped up out of the water and ripped her arm off. She had lost over 60 percent of her blood. | Eric Reichardt, 42 || September 16, 2001 || Unconfirmed, possibly a bull shark or tiger shark || This death was officially classified as a drowning by the [[Broward County, Florida]] medical examiner's office; however, it is listed as a fatal shark attack by the [[International Shark Attack File]]. Reichardt drowned while diving on the wreck of the ''Ronald B. Johnson'' in {{convert|270|ft|m}} of water {{convert|2|mi|km}} off [[Pompano Beach, Florida]] while fighting off a shark. His [[diving regulator]] may have fallen out of his mouth, causing him to drown.{{cite web | title=ISAF concludes shark killed Florida diver | url=http://www.cdnn.info/special-report/sharkbyte/sharktimeline.html | accessdate=2006-04-18 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414131947/http://www.cdnn.info/special-report/sharkbyte/sharktimeline.html | archivedate=2006-04-14 | df= }} |- | Sergei Zaloukaev, 28 || September 3, 2001 || Unconfirmed, experts are divided whether it was a bull shark or a tiger shark || Zaloukaev was killed while swimming with his girlfriend in the surf off [[Avon, North Carolina|Avon]], [[Hatteras Island]], [[Dare County, North Carolina]]; his girlfriend, Natalia Slobodskaya, was severely injured in the attack, but survived.{{cite news | title=Experts Blame Bull Sharks in Two Attacks |author1=Glod, Maria |author2=Lenhart, Jennifer |lastauthoramp=yes| publisher=Washington Post.com | date=September 7, 2001 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn?pagename=article&node=digest&contentId=A54303-2001Sep6 | accessdate=2006-04-18}} |- | David Peltier, 10 || September 1, 2001 || Unconfirmed, possibly a bull shark || Peltier was killed while surfing with his father and brothers at [[Sandbridge Beach]], south of [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]], [[Virginia]]. He died of severe injuries to the lower leg. |- | Thadeus Kubinski, 69 || August 30, 2000 || [[Bull shark]] || Kubinski was killed while swimming in [[Pinellas County, Florida]]. Witnesses said Kubinski had jumped into the water from the dock behind his home for his daily swim and was splashing vigorously. The shark raced toward him with its dorsal fin out of the water. He died from massive blood loss and organ damage before rescuers could get to him. The shark was estimated to be {{convert|9|ft|m|0}} long and weigh {{convert|400|lb|kg|0}}.{{cite news | title=Expert: Splash triggered feeding shark to attack |author1=Minai, Leanora |author2=Wimmer, Amy |lastauthoramp=yes| publisher=St. Petersburg Times | date=September 1, 2000 | url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/090100/news_pf/TampaBay/Expert__Splash_trigge.shtml | accessdate=2006-04-18}}{{cite web | title=The Bull Shark | author=McCollam, Douglas | publisher= slate.com | date=July 18, 2001 | url=http://www.slate.com/default.aspx?id=112116 | accessdate=2006-04-19}} |} ==1990s== {|class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Nahid Davoodabai, 29 || March 18, 1999 || Unconfirmed, presumed to be a tiger shark || This unconfirmed fatal attack occurred in channel waters off the west coast of [[Maui, Hawaii]]. The victim's husband, Manoucher Monazzami, stated to authorities that he and his wife were blown offshore while kayaking late in the afternoon. Their double kayak capsized repeatedly in rough channel waters, and Davoodabai was soon unable to get back onto the kayak due to fatigue. She was attacked at dusk by a "large shark", losing her arm. Monazzami was unable to control his injured wife's bleeding or keep her body on the kayak due to ocean conditions. Monazzami was found two days later on nearby [[Kahoolawe]] island with the kayak, paddles, and a life jacket. His wife's body was never recovered. Some investigators did not believe this version of events.{{cite news | title=Company not guilty in Maui kayak death | publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin | author=Barayuga, Debra | date=May 9, 2003 | url=http://www.starbulletin.com/2003/05/09/news/story12.html | accessdate=2006-04-18}} |- | James Willie Tellasmon, 9 || November 21, 1998 || [[Tiger shark]] || Killed while swimming off Ocean Beach, Jaycee Park, [[Indian River County, Florida]], US Coast Guard Station Fort Pierce recovered the body the following day. The nature of the wounds allowed experts to conclusively establish the shark was a tiger shark, about {{convert|6|ft}} long. |- | William Covert, 25 || September 13, 1995 || [[Bull shark]] || A scuba diver, Covert was presumed to have been killed by a {{convert|10|-|12|ft|adj=on}} bull shark near [[Alligator Reef]] off [[Islamorada, Florida|Islamorada]], [[Monroe County, Florida]]. His body was never recovered. |- | James Robinson, 42 || December 9, 1994 || [[Great white shark]] || Robinson was killed while diving for sea urchins off Harris Point, [[San Miguel Island]], California. The shark was estimated to be {{convert|16|-|18|ft}} feet long. |- | Michelle von Emster, 25 || April 16, 1994 || Great White Shark {{cite news | title=Local lobsterman gets a too-close view of a great white shark | publisher=San Diego Union-Tribune | author=Zieralski, Ed | date=November 30, 2002 | url=http://www.utsandiego.com/sports/outdoors/20021130-9999_mz1s30power.html | accessdate=2015-07-05}} || von Emster was killed while swimming off [[Point Loma, San Diego, California]]. The [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]] medical examiner's office ruled she was killed in a shark attack; however, some in the law enforcement community have questioned this conclusion and feel she may have been murdered and dumped in the [[Pacific Ocean]].{{cite web | title=Global Shark Attack File-Incident Log | url=http://sharkattackfile.net/incidentlog.htm | accessdate=2008-05-18}} |- | Jim Broach || January 31, 1994 || Tiger shark || Broach was killed while surfing at Velzyland on the [[North Shore (Oahu)|North Shore]] of [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. |- | Daniel McMoyler || December 1993 || Tiger shark || On January 11, 1994, McMoyler's remains washed up on the beach at [[Waipio, Hawaii]]. He is thought to have been killed by an {{convert|8|ft|m|0|adj=on}} tiger shark while surfing sometime during the previous month. |- | Aaron A. Romento, 18 || November 5, 1992 || Tiger shark || Romento was attacked and killed while bodyboarding at 9:45 a.m. in shallow, clear water approximately {{convert|90|ft}} from shore off Ke{{okina}}eau Beach Park, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. His right leg was severely bitten in three places by a {{convert|10|-|12|ft|adj=on}} tiger shark, and he died of blood loss a short time after swimming to shore.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=82}} |- | Bryan Adona, 29 || February 19, 1992 || Tiger shark || Adona was presumed to have been killed in the late afternoon by a tiger shark when he did not return from bodyboarding west of [[Waimea Bay]], [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. There were no witnesses to the attack; however, his body board was found the following morning with a {{convert|16|in|cm|adj=on}} crescent-shaped piece missing that experts said was made by a large tiger shark. Numerous witnesses, including the last person to see Adona alive, reported seeing a large shark in the vicinity prior to the attack.{{Harvnb|Balazs|pp=80–81}} |- | Martha Joy Morrell, 41 || November 26, 1991 || Tiger shark || Fatally attacked around 9 a.m., Morrell was attacked while snorkeling {{convert|100|yd}} from shore on west side of [[Maui, Hawaii]] at [[Olowalu]], less than a mile from Camp Pecusa. The attack by the {{convert|8|-|11|ft|adj=on}} tiger shark occurred in {{convert|10|-|15|ft}} of water and was witnessed by victim's snorkeling partner and groundskeeper. Morrell's body was recovered and later autopsied at Maui Memorial Hospital by the County Coroner. Injuries included amputation of left arm at the shoulder, right forearm, left leg above the hip joint, and right foot/lower leg.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=80}} |- | Suk Kyu (Steve) Park || November 19, 1991 || [[Tiger shark]] || Park was swept out to sea by a large wave while fishing from the rocky coastline at Maliko Point, [[Maui, Hawaii]] at around 4:30 p.m. Described as very healthy and a strong swimmer, Park was treading water before signaling his son to call for help. Rescuers arrived about 30 minutes later, by which time the victim had disappeared. His body was never recovered, although his shorts and shirt were discovered the following morning by rescue divers with large portions missing from the left side, consistent with an attack by a {{convert|12|ft|adj=on}} tiger shark.{{Harvnb|Balazs|pp=79–80}} |- | Roy T. Tanaka || February 17, 1990 || Tiger shark || Tanaka was scuba diving and spearing parrotfish with his partner, Jake Hernandez, at a depth of {{convert|40|ft}}, about {{convert|600|ft}} from the shore. The victim vanished around 9:30 p.m. at [[Kaneohe, Hawaii|Mokapu]], near the [[Marine Corps Air Station Kaneohe Bay|Marine Corps Air Station]], [[Honolulu, Hawaii]]. Diving equipment was later found. The next day around 3 p.m., a floating body (which was missing its left arm) was sighted from a helicopter in the waters between [[Mānana|Mānana Island]] and Makai pier. Several large sharks, apparently reacting to the helicopter's presence, proceeded to devour all but the body's torso and legs before it could be retrieved.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=78}} |} ==1980s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Ray Mehl, Jr. || October 14, 1989 || [[Tiger shark]] || This victim was scuba diving with a partner at a depth of {{convert|27|ft}}, about {{convert|750|ft}} from shore near the [[Hawaiian Electric Industries|HECO power plant]] at Kahe Point, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. He had been in the water for 10–15 minutes before vanishing around 4:30 p.m. His partner conducted a search of the area where water visibility was around {{convert|30|ft}}, but could not locate Mehl. The following morning, a decapitated body was spotted by rescue divers {{convert|200|ft}} west of Mehl's last known location, but before it could be retrieved, a large tiger shark suddenly appeared and proceeded to devour what remained of the body. Mehl's partner noted the parrotfish had been exhibiting "unusual behavior" just prior to his disappearance. |- | Tamara McAllister, 24, Roy Jeffrey Stoddard, 24 || January 26, 1989 || [[Great white shark]] || McAllister was killed while kayaking off the coast of [[Malibu, California]] with her boyfriend, Roy Jeffrey Stoddard. McAllister's body was found floating face down two days later, with large sections from her legs and buttocks missing; no trace of Stoddard was ever found. |- | John P. Martin, 38 || September 13, 1988 || [[Bull shark]] || Martin was killed while snorkeling around Shell Island near [[Panama City, Florida]]. A {{convert|10|ft|m|0|adj=on}}-long bull shark had caused fatal thigh and hand wounds. |- | Avery Goo || April 15, 1988 || Unconfirmed || This victim's {{convert|21|ft|adj=on}} powerboat capsized in turbulent water off the coast of [[Waihee, Hawaii|Waihee]], [[Maui, Hawaii]]. Pieces of human flesh consisting of stomach, intestines, and pancreas washed up along the Waihee shoreline several days later.{{Harvnb|Balazs|pp=76}} |- | Daniel Kennedy || April 15, 1987 || Unconfirmed || Kennedy was presumed to have been killed by a shark while swimming out to an anchored sailboat near [[Kailua, Hawaii County, Hawaii|Kailua-Kona]], Hawaii. While his body was never recovered, his swim trunks were found bitten in half on the sea floor. |- | Levi Chandler || April 20, 1986 || Unconfirmed || Chandler was fishing from the rocky shore at [[Kalihiwai, Hawaii|Kalihiwai Point]], [[Kauai, Hawaii]] before falling into the water and disappearing. Police divers searching the area encountered a large shark swimming in the vicinity and retrieved floating pieces of clothing and human flesh. The victim may have drowned before being consumed. |- | Male diver, 67 || August 1985 || Unconfirmed || This victim was presumed to have been killed by a shark in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] off the coast of Florida. His body was never recovered. Some of his equipment — a diving regulator, swim fin, and bathing suit — were found, showing teethmarks. |- | Omar Conger, 28 || September 15, 1984 || Great white shark || Conger was attacked at 8:30 a.m. while free-diving for abalone with a friend, Chris Rehm, 33, in {{convert|15|ft|m}} of water about {{convert|164|yd}} from shore near Pigeon Point, between [[Half Moon Bay, California|Half Moon Bay]] and [[Santa Cruz, California]]. The men had been in the water for about 20–30 minutes before the attack occurred. Water conditions were calm, but visibility was less than {{convert|3.3|ft|m|0}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.sharkresearchcommittee.com/unprovoked_diver.htm |title=Unprovoked White Shark Attacks on Divers |publisher=Shark Research Committee |accessdate=26 October 2010}} Conger was struck twice, with the shark initially thrashing and pulling him underwater before resurfacing and swimming away. Rehm pulled Conger onto an inflatable surf mat, but Conger bled to death before they could reach shore.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2gIiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_6UFAAAAIBAJ&dq=omar-conger%20shark&pg=3294%2C5638742 |title=Swimmers warned of fatal shark attack |date=September 17, 1984 |publisher=Reading Eagle |location=Reading, PA |accessdate=28 October 2010}} Injuries to Conger's thighs were extensive (both femoral arteries were severed), and his hands and buttocks were severely bitten; the wounds suggest an attacking great white shark about {{convert|14|-|16|ft}} long. Conger's black wetsuit may have increased the likelihood the shark mistook him for a seal.{{cite news |title=Environment: Dangers of the Red Triangle |author=Angier, Natalie |authorlink=Natalie Angier |author2=Jeff Gottlieb |newspaper=Time Magazine |date=November 19, 1984 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,950217,00.html |accessdate=28 October 2010}} |- | Mark Adams, 42 || October 1982 || Unconfirmed || He was caught in a tropical storm along with John Lippoth, Meg Cooney Brad Cavanagh and [[Deborah Scaling Kiley]] in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean on a raft with no survival equipment and was attacked. |- | Lewis Archer Boren, 24 || December 19, 1981 || Great white shark || Boren was attacked on December 19 while surfing alone at South [[Moss Beach]], Spanish Bay, [[Monterey, California]]. He was last seen by friends at approximately 2 p.m.{{cite journal |last1=Lea |first1=Robert N. |last2=Miller |first2=Daniel J. |year=1984 |title=Shark attacks off the California and Oregon coast: an update, 1980–84 |pages=22 |publisher=California Department of Fish and Game, Marine Resources Branch |location=Monterey, CA |url=http://aquaticcommons.org/483/1/shark_attacks_uipdate.pdf |accessdate=2 April 2011 }} The next day, two surfers stumbled upon Boren's [[kneeboard]], which had washed ashore at [[Asilomar State Beach]] with an {{convert|18|in|cm|adj=on}}, crescent-shaped bite taken out of one side; the board's missing piece was found nearby. Analysis of the bite mark showed the presence of embedded teeth fragments from a great white shark. At 11 a.m. on December 24, Boren's body was spotted by a park ranger near [[Pacific Grove, California|Pacific Grove]], about {{convert|0.62|mi|km|0}} from the attack site. Boren, who had been wearing a dark wetsuit, was believed to have been lying on his yellow kneeboard in {{convert|10|ft|m|0}} of water just beyond the break point, when a great white shark struck from the left side, biting through both Boren and his board. Water conditions were rough, with average temperatures for that time of year and excellent visibility. Boren was bitten once, his massive wound extending from beneath his left armpit to just above the hip, and stretching more than halfway across his body. The attacking shark is estimated to have been {{convert|17|-|19|ft}} long. |- | Mark Meeker, 26 || September 15, 1981 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull shark || Meeker was killed while swimming between [[Anna Maria Island]] and [[Egmont Key State Park]] in [[Tampa Bay]], [[Manatee County, Florida]]. He was found dead the next day. He had taken off his bathing suit to use the drawstring as a makeshift tourniquet on his right calf. |- | Christy Wapniarski, 19 || August 10, 1981 ||Unconfirmed, probably a bull or tiger shark || A catamaran Wapniarski was riding on had capsized the night before off of [[Daytona Beach]], [[Volusia County, Florida]]. She was presumably killed by a shark while attempting to swim to shore at daybreak. |- | Roger B. Garletts || May 21, 1981 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Garletts disappeared while scuba diving and spearfishing at a depth of {{convert|60|-|80|ft}} in murky, choppy water at [[Haʻena State Park|Haena Beach Park]], [[Kauai, Hawaii]]. His recovered dive gear and shredded wetsuit, which bore numerous teeth marks, were suggestive of a fatal shark attack.{{Harvnb|Balazs|pp=75}} |} ==1970s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Unidentified male || 1979 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || This victim disappeared while fishing from shore at [[Kohala, Hawaii|South Kohala]], [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island, Hawaii]]. Police divers only recovered the elderly man's severed hand and a flashlight. |- | Danson Nakaima || 1976 || bull shark || Nakaima was presumed to have been killed while scuba diving for [[black coral]] at a depth of {{convert|180|ft}} off [[Lahaina]], [[Maui, Hawaii]]. Approximately 30 large sharks were later seen near his partially devoured remains. |- | Stephen C. Powell || July 16, 1976 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Killed by a shark while scuba diving off [[Koloa, Hawaii|Koloa]], [[Kauai, Hawaii]], only the lower portion of Powell's body was recovered. |- | John Carter, 17 || July 20, 1974 || Unconfirmed || Carter was killed by a school of small sharks while swimming in the Back River on the southern end of [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah Beach]], [[Chatham County, Georgia]]. |- |Billy Horne, 10 || July 2, 1974 || [[Oceanic whitetip shark]] || While adrift after the yacht he was in caught on fire and sank, Horne was killed by a shark in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] off the coast of Florida. |- | Rodney Temple || October 14, 1972 || Oceanic whitetip shark (two) || Temple was scuba diving with partners [[Bret Gilliam]] and Robbie McIlvaine in calm {{convert|80|°F}} water with {{convert|150|ft}} of visibility some {{convert|300|yd}} from shore.{{Harvnb|Baldridge|p=177}}{{cite web |url=http://www.undercurrent.org/blog/2009/09/10/diving-shark-attack/ |title=Shark Attack! |author=Gilliam, Bret |date=September 10, 2009 |publisher=undercurrent.org |accessdate=29 October 2010}} The experienced divers were retrieving research samples from Cane Bay, [[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands]]. At a depth of {{convert|210|ft}}, they noted two oceanic whitetips circling them.{{cite news |title=25 Years Later, Memories of Shark Attack Remain Vivid |author=Thomas, Pete |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=November 20, 1996 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-11-20/sports/sp-1059_1_sand-bass |accessdate=30 October 2010}} Gilliam and McIlvaine began ascending to the surface first, momentarily [[Decompression stop|decompressing]] on a reef ledge at {{convert|175|ft}} before noticing bubbles rising from Temple's position below. Gilliam descended and saw a {{convert|12|ft|adj=on}} whitetip biting Temple's left thigh, and the second larger shark attacking immediately afterward and severing Temple's lower left leg. Gilliam grabbed Temple's shoulder harness and began kicking to the surface, but the sharks pulled the two men deeper to {{convert|400|ft}}, tearing into Temple's abdomen and pulling him out of Gilliam's arms. Gilliam and McIlvaine successfully surfaced and survived; Temple's body was never recovered. This may be the deepest shark attack on record. |- | Ernie Reathaford || March 31, 1970 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Swept out to sea by strong surf, Reathaford was bodyboarding at [[Waimea Bay, Hawaii|Waimea Bay]], [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. A {{convert|15|-|18|ft|adj=on}} shark was observed in the area.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=74}} |- |} ==1960s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Unidentified male || September 20, 1967|| Tiger shark || This victim lost at sea when his boat capsized in the waters between the Hawaiian islands of [[Oahu]] and [[Molokai]]. Part of the victim's remains were recovered from the stomach of a captured {{convert|11|ft|adj=on}} tiger shark. |- | [[Lieutenant (junior grade)|LTJG]] John W. Gibson, 25 || April 20, 1963 || [[Galapagos shark]] || Gibson was attacked at about 1:30 p.m. roughly {{convert|33|yd}} from shore while attempting to swim across [[Magens Bay]], [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]], [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]. Water conditions were calm with a temperature of approximately {{convert|82.4|°F|0}} and a depth of {{convert|40|ft}}.{{cite journal |last1=Randall |first1=John E. |date=December 1963 |title=A fatal attack by the shark, Carcharhinus Galapagensis, at St. Thomas, Virgin Islands |journal=Caribbean Journal of Science |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=201–205 |url=http://academic.uprm.edu/publications/cjs/VOL03/P201-206.PDF }} A vacationing tourist acquainted with Gibson, Donna M. Waugh, 25, aided him in swimming to shore, but he succumbed to his injuries and was pronounced dead at 2 p.m.{{cite news |title=Women: The Heroine |newspaper=Time Magazine |date=November 1, 1963 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,875301,00.html |accessdate=28 October 2010}}{{cite journal |date=November 1964 |title=Heroine Joins SPARs |journal=The Coast Guard Reservist |publisher=Commandant, U.S. Coast Guard |location=Washington, D.C. |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages= |url=http://www.uscg.mil/RESERVIST/mag1964/November%201964/November1964.pdf}} Gibson's wounds included a dismembered right hand, a mangled left shoulder, and a badly bitten right thigh and hip (including a severed [[femoral artery]]). The next day, a {{convert|10|ft|adj=on|0}} male Galapagos shark was baited and hooked in the bay, its stomach containing Gibson's missing hand and other human remains; the shark's jaws are now on display at the [[University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez]]'s marine laboratory.{{Harvnb|Ricciuti|p=37}} This is the first authenticated attack in the Virgin Islands. |- | Roy C. Kametani || April 8, 1963 || Tiger shark || Kametami was swept out to sea while picking [[opihi]] at [[Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area|Hapuna Beach]], Hawaii. Parts of the body were later recovered. The victim may have drowned before being consumed. |- | Hans Fix, 40 || August 19, 1962 || Bull shark || Fix was killed while surf fishing in waist-deep water at Andy Bowie Park, [[Padre Island]], near [[Port Isabel, Texas]]. |- | Jacob Horn, 45 || October 1961 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull or tiger shark || Presumed killed by a shark; Horn's mutilated body washed ashore near [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]], [[Palm Beach County, Florida]]. |- | William J. Dandridge, 23 || June 24, 1961 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull or tiger shark || Killed while scuba diving and spear fishing {{convert|9|mi|km|0}} east of [[Key Biscayne]], [[Dade County, Florida]], the left side of Dandridge's torso, including the left arm, was devoured. |- | Harold Riley || December 27, 1960 || Tiger shark || Swept out to sea while net fishing at Maile Point, [[Oahu, Hawaii]], Riley was seen being attacked by a {{convert|20|ft|adj=on}} shark. His body was recovered off the coast of [[Nanakuli]].{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=73}} |- | Young Marine Recruit || August 1960 || Unconfirmed || This victim was killed while swimming from camp off [[Parris Island, South Carolina]]. |} ==1950s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Lt. James C. Neal, 26 || August 15, 1959 || Unconfirmed || Neal was free-diving with four friends in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] about {{convert|6|mi}} off [[Panama City]], [[Florida]]. Neal's friends surfaced and threw him a line after entering their cruise boat; Neal, however, failed to climb up. One of the men, Gary Seymour, 21, went back into the water to search for Neal, but was "attacked by two big sharks", managing to escape by hiding in a crevice in the coral reef.{{cite news |title=Lieutenant Eaten By Shark? |newspaper=The Miami News |date=August 17, 1959 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rV4zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6-oFAAAAIBAJ&dq=james-neal%20shark&pg=1603%2C591786 |agency=United Press International |accessdate=30 October 2010}} Navy divers from the U.S. Naval Mine Defense Laboratory found Neal's swim fins, face mask, and lead diving weights, all showing bite marks. Neal's swim trunks and parts of his undershirt were also found, bloodstained and ripped.{{cite news |title=Army Lieutenant Victim Of Sharks While Skin Diving |newspaper=Lakeland Ledger |date=August 17, 1959 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b8gSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LfoDAAAAIBAJ&dq=james-c-neal&pg=2800%2C2468030 |accessdate=30 October 2010}} His body was never recovered. Charter boat captain Charles House reported his crew baited and hooked two {{convert|12|ft|adj=on}} sharks some {{convert|300|ft}} from Neal's last known location about an hour before he vanished. |- | Robert Lyell Pamperin, 33 || June 14, 1959 || Great white shark || Pamperin was free-diving with a friend, Gerald Lehrer, 30, for abalone at Alligator Head, [[La Jolla Cove]], [[La Jolla, California]]. The men were {{convert|55|yd}} from shore, diving at a depth of {{convert|36|-|42|ft}}; the water temperature was {{convert|68|°F}} with {{convert|23|ft|0}} of visibility. Around 5:10 p.m., Lehrer heard Pamperin screaming for help, his thrashing body momentarily upright and waist-high out of the water before submerging. Lehrer dove and spotted a {{convert|20|-|23|ft|adj=on|0}} shark thrashing Pamperin in its mouth.{{Harvnb|Allen|pp=89–90}} Lehrer dove several times in a futile effort to scare off the shark before swimming to land. The attack was witnessed by several people onshore. An extensive search by police divers and the Coast Guard failed to recover Pamperin's body; only a single swim fin was found. He was seen being swallowed whole, feet-first.{{cite news|title=Local lobsterman gets a too-close view of a great white shark |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/outdoors/20021130-9999_mz1s30power.html |author=Zieralski, Ed |publisher=The San Diego Union-Tribune |date=November 30, 2002 |accessdate=2010-10-26}} |- | Albert Kogler, Jr., 18 || May 7, 1959 || Great white shark || Kogler was killed while swimming in less than {{convert|15|ft|m}} of water off [[Baker Beach]], [[San Francisco, California]]. |- | William S. Weaver, 15 || December 13, 1958 || Tiger shark || While surfing near the [[Na Mokulua|Mokulua Islands]] off Lanikai, [[Oahu, Hawaii]], Weaver was killed when his leg was severed. Rescue personnel recovering his body two hours later observed a {{convert|15|-|25|ft|adj=on}} shark in the vicinity. |- | Sailor from tuna vessel, 22 || December 12, 1958 || Tiger shark || A sailor who was cleaning the hull of tuna vessel No. 12, the ''Taiyo Marei'', fell overboard at approximately 11:00 a.m. in [[Pago Pago Harbor]], [[Tutuila]], American Samoa. His body was recovered from the [[wharf]] at the [[Van Camp Seafood Company]]'s tuna cannery with bite wounds to the left thigh and hip. |- | Angel Escartin, 35 || July 10, 1958 || Unconfirmed || Autopsy report concluded Escartin was bitten by a shark off [[Key West]], [[Monroe County, Florida]] while still alive. |- | Rupert Wade, 57 || July 15, 1957 || Great white shark || Wade was killed while swimming in the surf at Atlantic Beach, [[Salter Path, North Carolina|Salter Path]], [[Carteret County, North Carolina]]. |- | Peter Savino, 25 || April 28, 1957 || Great white shark || Savino was killed at approximately 1:30 p.m. while swimming with a friend, Daniel Hogan, 22, off Atascadero Beach, [[Morro Bay, California]].{{Harvnb|Allen|pp=88–89}}{{cite news |title=Man Feared Victim Of Shark |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NUAwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aUgDAAAAIBAJ&dq=peter-savino&pg=6241%2C6190635 |newspaper=Deseret News |location=Salt Lake City, UT |date=April 27, 1957 |accessdate=27 January 2011}} After being swept out some {{convert|300|-|600|yd}} from shore by a strong tide, the two started a swim back, though Savino began to tire. As Hogan towed Savino, a shark appeared and nudged Savino with enough force to draw blood. Aware of the imminent danger, the men started a furious race to shore, but when Hogan looked back to check on his friend, Savino had disappeared. The U.S. Coast Guard sent a [[Launch (boat)|launch]] to the area, and Executive Officer James C. Knight reported seeing a {{convert|20|-|21|ft|adj=on|1}} shark swim by, though by the time the crew had returned to the spot with armaments, the shark had disappeared. Despite the following day's search, Savino's body was never recovered. This attack bears similarities to the attack on Robert Pamperin in June 1959. |- | Sailor from tuna vessel, 28 || August 8, 1955 || [[Blue shark]] || A sailor received fatal bite wounds to the abdomen while taking a morning swim in Pago Pago Bay near the Van Camp Seafood Company tuna cannery, [[Tutuila]], American Samoa. |- | Capt. Kosuo Mizokawa, 27 || January 6, 1955 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Mizokawa was attacked after diving overboard and swimming near the stern of the Japanese-flagged trawler near the Van Camp Seafood Company tuna cannery in [[Pago Pago Harbor]], [[Tutuila]], American Samoa.{{Harvnb|Coppleson|p=263}} |- | Harold Souza, 15 || July 26, 1953 || Tiger shark || Souza was killed while spearfishing off Maile Beach, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. A {{convert|10|ft|adj=on}} shark was observed in the vicinity. |- | Leonard Gant || April 15, 1953 || Tiger shark || Gant was killed by a shark off McGregor Point, [[Maui, Hawaii]] swimming after canoe he was in became swamped. |- | Gordon S. Chun || April 8, 1953 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Swept into the sea while fishing from shore, Chun's recovered body was mutilated by sharks. He may have drowned near Wailupe, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. |- | Arthur Barry Lyle Wilson, 17 || December 7, 1952 || Great white shark || Wilson was attacked at approximately 2:00 p.m. while swimming near Lover's Point, [[Pacific Grove, California]] with a friend, Brookner W. Grady, Jr., 15. Wilson was some {{convert|25|yd}} from shore in {{convert|30|ft|0}} of water.{{cite journal |last1=Bolin |first1=Rolf L |year=1954 |title=Report on a Fatal Attack by a Shark |journal=Pacific Science |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=105–8 |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |url=http://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/9119/1/vol8n1-105-108.pdf |accessdate=27 January 2011}} Wave faces averaged {{convert|8|ft}}, with {{convert|6|-|8|ft}} of visibility in the {{convert|55|°F}} water. Suddenly, a {{convert|12|-|15|ft|adj=on}} shark attacked Wilson, thrashing him and lifting him several feet into the air. Grady swam to his friend's aid and began gouging the shark's eye with a hunting knife.{{cite news |title=Shark Disaster Heroes Hailed, Seek Medals For 5 in Rescue Try |newspaper=Monterey Peninsula Herald |page=1 |date=December 9, 1952 |location=Monterey, CA }} Four other swimmers helped pull the unconscious Wilson onto an inner tube, reaching shore some 20–30 minutes later with the shark circling the entire way.{{cite news |title=Witnesses Tell of Attack |newspaper=Monterey Peninsula Herald |page=1 |date=December 8, 1952 |location=Monterey, CA }} By then, Wilson had bled to death. His right leg was nearly bitten off in the attack; he also suffered a severed femoral artery, gashes to his left thigh, torso, and back, and a large chunk was torn out of his right buttock. The wounds suggest Wilson was bitten at least four times. The attack, which was witnessed by scores of beachgoers, is the first "authenticated" attack on the California coast. |- | Gerbacio Solano, 40 || December 3, 1952 || Tiger shark || Solano was killed by an extremely large shark described by witnesses as being in excess of {{convert|22|ft}} while swimming from his fishing boat, setting nets, at Maile Beach, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. |- | Shigeichi Kawamura || August 3, 1952 || Tiger shark || Kawamura disappeared while swimming between the Ala Moana channel and Kewalo Basin, Oahu, Hawaii. A shark bite was found on the right side of his body. |- | Male Pan Am pilot || 1952 || Unconfirmed || Killed while swimming near [[Key West, Florida]], the man was bitten in the groin area. |- | Alejandro Nodura || June 25, 1951 || Tiger shark || Swept out to sea while fishing at Kapehu Beach, Hawaii, the victim was last seen in the shark's mouth. |- | Gilbert S. Hotta || January 16, 1950 || Tiger shark || While fishing, Hotta was swept into the sea by a large wave near Kahakuloa, [[Maui, Hawaii]]. Three large tiger sharks were seen in the area the day of the accident. His torso was recovered from a "huge tiger shark" caught there three days later.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=72}} |} ==1940s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Ralph Reginald Rives, Jr., 20 || August 4, 1947 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull shark || Attacked while swimming in a canal {{convert|10|mi|km|-1}} north of [[St. Augustine, Florida]], Rives' leg was severely bitten. The [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] papers initially and erroneously reported this as a [[barracuda]] attack. He died in the hospital after attempts to save him were unsuccessful. |- | John Kuntsler || May 8, 1945 || Unconfirmed || Kunstler was killed while swimming in Ocracoke Inlet, North Carolina. |} ==1930s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | A. Thompson, Jr., 16 || June 16, 1937 || Unconfirmed || Killed by a shark while swimming in the ocean in about {{convert|4|ft}} of water near [[Galveston, Texas]], Thompson's right arm was torn off and his right leg and thigh were mangled. |- | Joseph Troy, Jr., 16 || July 25, 1936 || Great white shark || Attacked while swimming at HollyWoods Beach, [[Mattapoisett, Massachusetts]], As he swam in the waters off the beach, Joseph Troy Jr., 16, a summer visitor from Dorchester, was grabbed and bitten by a 6-foot shark and dragged underwater less than 50 yards from shore. The badly injured youth was rushed to St. Luke's Hospital in New Bedford. He died on the operating table that night while surgeons were amputating his left leg. The boy, along with a family friend, had been swimming out from the beach to meet the Black Cat, a catboat that had just picked up its mooring after a morning sail, when the shark attacked, Smith said. The Black Cat's owner, Hubert Fisher, jumped into his dinghy and, with the help of the other swimmer, Walter Stiles of Boston, got the boy aboard and took him to the beach. Using an old wooden door as a stretcher, neighbors carried the badly injured teen to a car and he was rushed to the hospital. The wind had been from the southeast the day before the attack, he said, a condition that roils the bottom and results in poor visibility. That could have been a critical factor, producing an instinctive reaction from the shark when it saw the flash of a swimmer's white leg, Smith said he believes. The Standard-Times report of the incident said Joseph Troy was still conscious when he was wheeled into the operating room for the amputation. The attending surgeon, Dr. E.D. Gardner, said the boy told him he was horrified not so much by the bite as the thought of being dragged down while in the grip of the shark. In the aftermath of the attack, beaches around Buzzards Bay were deserted and swimming came to a halt along much of the Massachusetts coast, the newspaper reported. Although the attack was without precedent, sharks had previously been observed in Buzzards Bay. Just a week earlier, a 6-foot shark had been caught in Marion harbor. |- | Jere W. Fountain, 38 || September 21, 1935 || Bull shark || Fountain was killed while swimming in Browns Inlet on the New River near Onslow Beach, North Carolina. |- | Richard Clark Best, Jr., 11 || June 20, 1934 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull or tiger shark || Best was killed while standing in the surf at [[Melbourne, Florida]]. |- | Thomas N. Martin, 24 || April 10, 1933 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull or tiger shark || Martin was killed in the surf at [[Miami Beach, Florida]]. |- | George Gaspar || September 2, 1931 || Tiger shark || Gaspar was swept out to sea by strong currents while fishing at [[Kāhala, Hawaii|Kāhala]], Oahu, Hawaii; his remains were recovered from the stomach of an {{convert|18|ft|adj=on}} shark near the [[Naval Air Station Barbers Point]].{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=70}} |- |} ==1920s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Unidentified boy || 1926 || Unconfirmed || This victim was killed by a shark in [[Sea Bright, New Jersey]]. |- | William J. Goins || May 18, 1926 || Great white shark || Goins was attacked while swimming off [[Haleiwa]], Oahu, Hawaii. Witnesses describe Goins as giving a loud shriek before suddenly disappearing beneath the surface. His remains were recovered from a {{convert|12.5|ft|adj=on}} great white shark captured off [[Kahuku, Hawaii|Kahuku]]. |- | Professor Winslow || November 1924 || Unconfirmed || Winslow died after both legs and arms were severely bitten by a shark in [[Santurce, Puerto Rico]]. |- | Miss Bourne || December 15, 1922 || Unconfirmed || Bourne died after her leg was bitten by a shark in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]. |- | Dorothy MacLatchie, 18 || June 17, 1922 || Unconfirmed || Killed by a "monster fish", MacLatchie was floating next to the Municipal Pier in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]]. |} ==1910s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Unidentified male || April 6, 1919 || Unconfirmed || This fisherman was knocked into the water and killed in the [[Florida Keys]]. |- | Tadaicai Mayamura || November 1918 || Unconfirmed || Mayamura, a Japanese worker fishing off the coast of Papaikou plantation in Hawaii, was swept off a rock by a large wave. Mayamura was later heard crying for help and seen struggling in the water in the presence of a shark dorsal fin. His body was not recovered.{{Citation|title=Japanese laborer is devoured by a shark|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=13 December 1918}} |- | [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916|Watson "Stanley" Fisher]], 24 || July 12, 1916 || Unconfirmed, experts are divided whether it was a bull or immature great white shark || Attacked while trying to recover Lester Stillwell's body in Matawan Creek, New Jersey, Fisher died at Monmouth Hospital in [[Long Branch, New Jersey]] a few hours after the attack.{{cite web | title=New Jersey History's Mysteries: The Matawan Man-Eater | url=http://www.njhm.com/matawanmaneater.htm | accessdate=2006-04-19 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020106102244/http://www.njhm.com/matawanmaneater.htm | archivedate=2002-01-06 | df= }} |- | [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916|Lester Stillwell]], 11 || July 12, 1916 || Unconfirmed, experts are divided whether it was a bull or immature great white shark|| Stillwell was killed while swimming with playmates in Matawan Creek, a narrow, brackish, tidal river near [[Matawan, New Jersey]]. |- | [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916|Charles Bruder]], 27 || July 6, 1916 || great white shark || Bruder was killed while swimming approximately {{convert|130|yd|m|-1}} from shore in [[Spring Lake, New Jersey]]. Both legs were bitten off. |- | [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916|Charles Van Sant]], 23 || July 1, 1916 || great white shark || Attacked while swimming in chest-deep water about {{convert|40|yd|m|-1}} from shore at [[Beach Haven, New Jersey]], Van Sant died on the beach of a severed [[femoral artery]] after being pulled from the surf. The incident was recorded as the first known shark attack in United States waters |- | Okomoto || March 3, 1914 || Unconfirmed || Washed into the sea while picking [[opihi]] at [[Honomu, Hawaii]], Okomoto was killed by two large sharks. |- | John Bloomquist || September 23, 1911 || Unconfirmed, probably a bull shark || Bloomquist was killed by a shark in the [[Galveston, Texas]] ship channel after he jumped overboard to rescue a companion. |- | Ship's pilot || September 20, 1911 || Unconfirmed || This victim fell overboard and was killed by a shark while swimming in [[Pensacola Bay]], [[Santa Rosa County, Florida]]. |- | Unidentified male || 1910 || Unconfirmed || This victim was attacked while fishing at [[Hilo, Hawaii]]. |- |} ==1900s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, Age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location; Comments |- | Ah Kim Chong, 19 || April 10, 1909 || Unconfirmed || The woman was reportedly swept away by large waves while gathering [[opihi]] along the rocky shoreline at [[Haiku-Pauwela, Hawaii|Pauwela]], Maui, Hawaii. A search party later witnessed a large shark devour what appeared to be part of the victim's body.{{Harvnb|Balazs|pp=69–70}} |- | Unidentified male || January 17, 1908 || Unconfirmed || Killed by a shark while gathering fish stunned by dynamite at Mana, Kauai, Hawaii. |- | Japanese fisherman || January 8, 1908 || Unconfirmed || Killed by a shark while gathering fish stunned by dynamite in Mana, Kauai, Hawaii. |- | Japanese fisherman || 1907 || Unconfirmed, probably a tiger shark || Fell into the water and killed by a shark while net fishing near [[Pepeekeo, Hawaii|Pepeekeo]], [[Honomu, Hawaii]]. |- | Belton Larkin || March 31, 1907 || Bull shark || Killed after a shark, which had been chasing a [[tarpon]], leapt into his small [[skiff]] breaking it apart near Punta Gorda, [[Charlotte County, Florida]]. Shark bit his side nearly cutting him in two. |- | Sutton Davis || July 29, 1905 || Unconfirmed || Killed while wading at Davis Shore, east of [[Beaufort, North Carolina]]. |- | Unidentified man || 1904 || Tiger shark || Man disappeared while swimming off [[Diamond Head, Hawaii|Diamond Head]], Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii. A shark was caught two days later with the head and body of a man (complete from the waist down with the exception of one leg) in its gut. The shark was described as "monstrous" in size. |- | Phil Kitchin || c. 1903 || Tiger shark || Killed while fishing at Koko Head, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. His foot was recovered two days later from a shark. |- | Hawaiian boy || August 2, 1902 || Tiger shark || Killed while catching crabs at Kalihi, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. Both arms were severed.{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=69}} |- | Unidentified Coast Guard Personnel || 1900–1905 || Unconfirmed || Killed while swimming at Ocracoke Inlet, North Carolina. |- | Emil Uhlbrecht and an unidentified person || July 14, 1900 || Tiger shark || Uhlbrecht was swept out to sea while hunting sea shells with friends at [[Makapuu Point]], Oahu, Hawaii. His positively identified foot was recovered from a tiger shark measuring {{convert|11|ft|9|in}} long which had been caught off [[Kakaako, Hawaii|Kakaako]], Oahu by John Kinipeki on September 17. The shark's stomach also contained a femur and pelvis thought to belong to another person, possibly one of several Chinese fisherman who had drowned in the harbor a few months prior. |- |} ==Before 1900== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age!! width="100"|Date!! width="150"|Species!! width="550"|Location, Comments |- | Delano Wood, 15 || Summer 1895 || Bull shark || Killed by a {{convert|10|ft|m|0|adj=on}} long shark while swimming in the Trout River, Panama Park near [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. |- | Capt. George Jacob Hanscheldt || 1853 or 1854 || Unconfirmed || Knocked overboard and killed by a shark near Fernandina Beach, [[Nassau County, Florida]]. |- | Charles Chambers || 1852 || Unconfirmed || Killed while wading ashore from a capsized vessel in Mount Pleasant, [[Charleston County, South Carolina]]. |- | James Kinney || March 1851 || Tiger Shark || Killed while swimming in Honolulu Harbor, [[Oahu, Hawaii]]. |- | Crew member of a pilot boat || c. 1840 || Unconfirmed, probably a Great white shark || Killed while treading water awaiting rescue after being accidentally thrown overboard in Charleston Harbor, [[Charleston County, South Carolina]]. Witnesses estimated the shark to be {{convert|25|ft|m|0}} long. |- | Joseph Blaney || July 12, 1830 || Great white shark || While fishing from a [[dory]] {{convert|5|mi|km|0}} east of [[Scituate, Massachusetts]]. |- | Unidentified male || 1828 || Unconfirmed, presumed to be a tiger shark || The victim was riding surf near [[Lahaina]], Maui, Hawaii at the time of the attack. The shark bit off most or all of the victim's limbs, while his torso was left floating in the water. The attack was reportedly witnessed "by a number of Hawaiian chiefs." |- | Nu'u-anu-pa'ahu || 1779 || Unconfirmed, presumed tiger shark || The victim was a young male who suffered a gash to one side of his buttocks following a shark attack at Maliu, Hawaii. The victim later died of his injuries at [[Pololū Valley]].{{Harvnb|Balazs|p=68}} |- | Unknown Male || June 1771 || Unconfirmed, probably [[Great White Shark]]. || This man was in off the coast of [[Massachusetts]] a boat with 2 other men when a shark came and bumped him out of the boat, biting him into 2. Another man shot the shark and brought the shark ashore, where the cut the open, and buried the mans remains.{{cite web | url=http://sharkattackfile.net/spreadsheets/pdf_directory/1771.07.12.R-Damiscotte.pdf | title= R-Damiscotte | work= sharkattackfile.net | accessdate=5 January 2017}} |- | Antony Van Corlear || 1642 || Unconfirmed, presumed bull shark || The victim was presumably killed and eaten by a shark on a stormy evening while attempting to swim across the [[Hudson River]] at the [[Spuyten Duyvil, Bronx|Spuyten Duyvil]], Riverdale, New York City. A witness to Van Corlaer's death stated that "the devil" in the shape of a giant fish swam up and proceeded to "seize the sturdy Antony by the leg and drag him beneath the waves."{{Harvnb|Fernicola|pp=104–105}} This may be the earliest recorded shark attack in the New World. |- |} == See also == {{Outline|Outline of sharks}} * [[Shark attack]] * [[Red Triangle (Pacific Ocean)]] * [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916]] * [[Animal attacks]] * [[List of fatal shark attacks in Australia]] (the country with second largest number of reported shark attacks) * [[List of fatal shark attacks in California]] * [[List of fatal shark attacks in South African territorial waters]] ; Species * [[List of fatal bear attacks in North America]] * [[List of fatal cougar attacks in North America]] * [[List of fatal snake bites in the United States]] * [[List of fatal alligator attacks in the United States by decade|List of fatal alligator attacks in the United States]] * [[List of wolf attacks in North America]] * [[Fatal dog attacks in the United States]] == References == ; Citations {{Reflist}} ; Bibliography {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |title = Shark Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance |author= Allen, Thomas B. |year=2001 |publisher=The Lyons Press |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-1-58574-174-8 |page = 312 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=O8qJf3QnEZ4C&lpg=PP1&dq=Shark%20Attacks%3A%20Their%20Causes%20and%20Avoidance&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=26 October 2010 |ref=CITEREFAllen }} * {{cite book |title=Shark Attack |last=Baldridge |first=Henry David |year=1974 |publisher=Berkley Publishing Group |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-0-425-03988-5 |pages=263 |ref=CITEREFBaldridge }} * {{citation |last1=Balazs |first1=George H. |editor1-first=Jim |editor1-last=Borg |contribution=Annotated List of Shark Attacks in the Hawaiian Islands, 1779–1993 |title=Tigers of the Sea: Hawaii's Deadly Sharks |url = http://swfsc.noaa.gov/publications/CR/1993/9307.PDF |accessdate=7 August 2010 |publisher=Mutual Publishing |location=Honolulu, HI |pages=63–83 |ref=CITEREFBalazs }} * {{cite book |title=Shark Attack |last=Coppleson |first=Victor Marcus |year=1958 |publisher=Angus & Robertson |location=Sydney |isbn=978-0-207-15350-1 |page = 266 |ref=CITEREFCoppleson }} * {{cite book |last1=Fernicola |first1=Richard G. |title=Twelve Days of Terror: A Definitive Investigation of the 1916 New Jersey Shark Attacks |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9uR4wAsbED8C&lpg=PA104&dq=%22Antony%20Van%20Corlear%22%20shark&pg=PA104#v=twopage&q&f=false |year=2001 |publisher=Lyons Press |location=Guilford, CT |isbn=978-1-58574-575-3 |accessdate=20 August 2011 |ref=CITEREFFernicola }} * {{cite book |title=Killers of the Seas: The Dangerous Creatures That Threaten Man in an Alien Environment |last=Ricciuti |first=Edward R. |year=2003 |publisher=Lyons Press |location=Guilford, CT |isbn=978-1-58574-869-3 |page = 272 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4E4u0MNbeAcC&lpg=PP1&dq=Killers%20of%20the%20Seas%3A%20The%20Dangerous%20Creatures%20That%20Threaten%20Man&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=28 October 2010 |ref = CITEREFRicciuti }} {{refend}} ; General references {{refbegin}} * {{cite web | title='''The International Shark Attack File''' | url = http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/sharks/isaf/isafabout.htm |accessdate=2006-04-18 }} * {{cite web | title='''Global Shark Attack File''' |url = http://sharkattackfile.net/ |accessdate=2006-04-18 }} * {{cite web |title='''Southeastern Outdoors''' ''Fatal Shark Attacks'' |url = http://www.southeasternoutdoors.com/wildlife/fish/fatal-shark-attacks.html |accessdate=2006-04-18 }} * {{cite book |title=Shark Attacks of the Twentieth Century: From the Pacific Coast of North America |last=Collier |first=Ralph S. |year=2003 |publisher=Scientia Publishing |location=Chatsworth, CA |isbn=978-0-9719717-4-5 |page = 296 }} {{refend}} == External links == *
